title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Act defines key terms such as "business entity" as any organization established for profit through commerce in the US, "commerce" as defined in the Consumer Product Safety Act, and "consumer" as an individual purchasing goods or services for personal use within the US. The curr_chunk defines terms related to consumer protection laws, including "customer service communication," "telecommunication," and "wire communication." These terms are crucial for understanding interactions between consumers and businesses in the US. The curr_chunk defines "telecommunication" as the transmission of chosen information without alteration, and "wire communication" as the transmission of various forms of data through wire connections. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location as required by SEC. 3. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, except if all employees or agents are in the United States or if the communication is initiated by a consumer to a foreign entity. Employees or agents of a business entity participating in customer service communications are exempt from disclosing their physical location if the communication is initiated by the consumer and the employee or agent is located outside the United States. Employees or agents of a business entity involved in customer service communications are exempt from disclosing their physical location if the communication is initiated by the consumer and the employee or agent is outside the United States. Emergency services are also excluded from these disclosure requirements. The Federal Trade Commission has the authority to exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from these requirements if compelling circumstances justify such exclusion. Additionally, there is a certification requirement for business entities to fulfill annually. The Commission can exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from the requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Business entities participating in customer service communications must certify annually to the Federal Trade Commission their compliance with the requirements. The Federal Trade Commission will establish necessary regulations within a year of the Act's enactment, and the requirements will apply to customer service communications one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to prevent violations of the Act and its regulations, with penalties for non-compliance. The Act incorporates the Federal Trade Commission Act's terms and provisions, including penalties for violations. The authority of the Federal Trade Commission is not limited by this Act.
